thread.title: Janet Yellen ally sees possible Fed rate-hike move soon
thread.title_full: Janet Yellen ally sees possible Fed rate-hike move soon - MarketWatch

author: David Harrison
title: Janet Yellen ally sees possible Fed rate-hike move soon
text:
SALT LAKE CITY—Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams said Thursday he sees the central bank raising short-term interest rates this year, perhaps as early as this month, as the economy continues to improve.
Williams, a close ally of Chairwoman Janet Yellen, said the Fed doesn’t need much new economic data before moving, adding that the decision to hold off on raising rates at the central bank’s September meeting was “a very close call.”
“When you have a close decision like that, it doesn’t take a lot of information to tip the balance,” Williams told reporters after a speech in Salt Lake City. “I would view October to be a completely live meeting.”
The Fed has two more scheduled policy meetings this year, Oct. 27-28 and Dec. 15-16. Some analysts have thought it unlikely central bankers would start lifting the benchmark short-term rate from near zero—a major move after holding it there for nearly seven years—at the October meeting, because Yellen doesn’t have a news conference scheduled that day, at which she could explain the action in great detail.
But the Fed has said it could schedule an impromptu news conference any time it likes, and Mr. Williams’s comments echo her statements that policy makers could act at any meeting.
Williams’s views are closely monitored as he is seen as a centrist on the Fed’s policy-making committee.
An extended version of this story can be found at WSJ.com
